articles.headline: Drive-Throughs That Predict Your Order? Restaurants Are Thinking Fast
articles.snippet: Inspired by pandemic lessons that kept customers in cars, chains are adding more lanes and curbside pickup, improving apps and testing menu boards that use artificial intelligence.
articles.abstract: Inspired by pandemic lessons that kept customers in cars, chains are adding more lanes and curbside pickup, improving apps and testing menu boards that use artificial intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starbucks has employees at hundreds of busy locations strolling through car lines, taking orders with hand-held devices so customers can get their caffeine fix a few seconds faster. Shake Shack, which has long emphasized that quality ingredients are worth waiting a few extra minutes for, will soon feature its first drive-through window. And the vast majority of new Chipotles this year will have “Chipotlanes,” where customers can drive up to a window and pull away with preordered meals in less than a minute.

articles.headline: Oprah, Meghan and Harry Draw 17.1 Million Viewers to CBS
articles.snippet: A two-hour special revived a faded TV genre, the “big-get” prime-time interview that once drew tens of millions for exclusive sit-downs with people like Michael Jackson and Monica Lewinsky.
articles.abstract: A two-hour special revived a faded TV genre, the “big-get” prime-time interview that once drew tens of millions for exclusive sit-downs with people like Michael Jackson and Monica Lewinsky.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oprah, Meghan and Harry drew a sizable audience on Sunday night, making for an old-style prime-time television moment in the age of on-demand viewing.

articles.headline: The Officers Danced at a Black Lives Matter Rally. Then They Stormed the Capitol.
articles.snippet: What appeared to be racial progress in rural Virginia turned into bitter conflict over a Confederate statue, the election and the Capitol riot. Now, people there foresee “a very dangerous time.”
articles.abstract: What appeared to be racial progress in rural Virginia turned into bitter conflict over a Confederate statue, the election and the Capitol riot. Now, people there foresee “a very dangerous time.”
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Inside the Lincoln Project’s Secrets, Side Deals and Scandals
articles.snippet: A civil war broke out in the group as it antagonized Donald Trump, with leaders splintering over financial arrangements and revelations of online harassment by a top official.
articles.abstract: A civil war broke out in the group as it antagonized Donald Trump, with leaders splintering over financial arrangements and revelations of online harassment by a top official.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days before the presidential election, the leadership of the anti-Trump Lincoln Project gathered at the Utah home of Steve Schmidt, one of the group’s co-founders, and listened as he plotted out the organization’s future.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Maggie Astor and Jo Becker

articles.headline: A Tale Old and New as Another Royal Wife Breaks Free
articles.snippet: A quarter-century after Princess Diana broke her silence about life among the British royals, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, did the same. Their stories were remarkably similar.
articles.abstract: A quarter-century after Princess Diana broke her silence about life among the British royals, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, did the same. Their stories were remarkably similar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anyone who remembers the funeral of Diana, the Princess of Wales, in 1997 can’t help being haunted by the wrenching sight of her two young sons, Princes William and Harry, walking slowly behind her coffin as it made its way to Westminster Abbey. Their hands were clasped in front; their heads were bowed. Harry looked so small in his suit.

articles.headline: Pandemic Relief Bill Fulfills Biden’s Promise to Expand Obamacare, for Two Years
articles.snippet: With its expanded subsidies for health plans under the Affordable Care Act, the coronavirus relief bill makes insurance more affordable, and puts health care on the ballot in 2022.
articles.abstract: With its expanded subsidies for health plans under the Affordable Care Act, the coronavirus relief bill makes insurance more affordable, and puts health care on the ballot in 2022.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief bill will fulfill one of his central campaign promises, to fill the holes in the Affordable Care Act and make health insurance affordable for more than a million middle-class Americans who could not afford insurance under the original law.

articles.headline: Biden Faces Challenge From Surge of Migrants at the Border
articles.snippet: The president’s promise of a more humane policy is being tested as more unaccompanied children seek to enter the United States from Mexico.
articles.abstract: The president’s promise of a more humane policy is being tested as more unaccompanied children seek to enter the United States from Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thousands of migrant children are backed up in United States detention facilities along the border with Mexico, part of a surge of immigration from Central Americans fleeing poverty and violence that could overwhelm President Biden’s attempt to create a more humane approach to those seeking entry into the country.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Tech’s Legal Shield Appears Likely to Survive as Congress Focuses on Details
articles.snippet: Section 230 isn’t expected to be revoked, but even the more modest proposals for weakening it could have effects that ripple across the internet.
articles.abstract: Section 230 isn’t expected to be revoked, but even the more modest proposals for weakening it could have effects that ripple across the internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump called multiple times for repealing the law that shields tech companies from legal responsibility over what people post. President Biden, as a candidate, said the law should be “revoked.”

articles.headline: ‘It’s Better to Walk Through a Minefield’: Victims of Myanmar’s Army Speak
articles.snippet: The military’s brutal practices go beyond killing protesters. Its soldiers have systematically raped women and forced villagers to be their human shields.
articles.abstract: The military’s brutal practices go beyond killing protesters. Its soldiers have systematically raped women and forced villagers to be their human shields.
articles.lead_paragraph: The soldiers from Myanmar’s army knocked on U Thein Aung’s door one morning last April as he was having tea with friends, and demanded that all of them accompany the platoon to another village.

articles.headline: Why Japan Is Holding Back as the World Rushes Toward Electric Cars
articles.snippet: The country’s stance would seem to put it on the wrong side of market trends. But with its huge investment in gasoline-electric hybrids, it has big reasons to proceed slowly.
articles.abstract: The country’s stance would seem to put it on the wrong side of market trends. But with its huge investment in gasoline-electric hybrids, it has big reasons to proceed slowly.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Just over a decade ago, Nissan became the first automaker to offer a mass-produced car that ran on batteries alone. That hatchback, the Leaf, has been a smash hit, at least by electric car standards, with more than 500,000 sold by the end of last year.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: Bitcoin’s Climate Problem
articles.snippet: As companies and investors increasingly say they are focused on climate and sustainability, the cryptocurrency’s huge carbon footprint could become a red flag.
articles.abstract: As companies and investors increasingly say they are focused on climate and sustainability, the cryptocurrency’s huge carbon footprint could become a red flag.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Bitcoin uses more electricity per transaction than any other method known to mankind, and so it’s not a great climate thing.”
